page.lettertext:
fol.5r
May it please your good L. The bearer heereof
M
r
Brune
, whose l
re
unto me fr
o
Amsterdam
I s
e
t in my last
e 16 of this moneth, up
o
e sight
of my answear, is come hither to
e Hage, and is very
well c
o
tented, up
o
talke betweene us, to surcease
his suite in these c
o
treis, and repaire in
son to
your L. w
t
out attending any passeport. For I have
fully
suaded him,
t
e cariage of my l
re
to yo
r
L. and indorsed up
o
, For her
Hig
es
special service,
will be warr
a
t good enough to
tect him fr
o
his
creditours: and though it were not suffici
e
t, yet
e occa
o
n of his c
o
ming being know
e
to your L.
he might be well assured,
t
p
nt
order will be
taken for his safe being there, w
t
further considera
o
n
for his charges and travail. And forasmuche
as those maters, w
c
he will signify unto you,
c
o
cerne some great abuses,
t
are practised
heere, he thought it very re
q
sit, to discover them
unto me: and I attend to knowe up
o
it, howe
your L. will be pleased to c
o
mand me to
ceede.
What disorders are c
o
mitted in
e Mintes
of these c
o
treis, aswell in regard of
e multitude
of th
e
, as of other badde courses, M
r
Brune can
informe you, as muche as is needefull. The state
of
e c
o
trey doth griefue at it greatly, and finde
very hardely any meanes, as this gouvernm
t
standes,
to redresse it by autority. Nevertheles at their
last assembly in Novem
b
they resolved w
t
this co
u
cel
to establishe those orders,
t
were published by
Placart, in
e yere 86, w
t
c
o
sent of my L. of
Leicester. M
r
Brune hath w
t
him a copie of
e
Placart, and I have sent an extract heereinclosed
of their last resolu
o
n. Having lately bin
enjoined, by a l
re
fr
o
her M
tie
to resume
e cause
fol.5v
of
Coronel Sonoy
, I have delivered he[r letter in]
their ordinary college, and as her Hig
es
[required]
have touched them roundely for
e sleight, [regard that]
they have had to her instant intercession, [which I also]
exhibited in writing unto th
e
, and have sent [you the]
transcript. I have also c
o
moned in [such sort]
w
t
some in
ticular,
t
nowe I am in hope, [more than]
ever heeretofore. Howbeit because it [is a]
mater
t
c
a
not be resolved but in a meet[ing of]
e Deputies of all
e townes of
Holland,
w
c
as[semble]
not heere til
e 28 of
e next, they have [differred]
till then to determine up
o
it. In
e meane [while]
it will steede
e Coronel very muche, if [her Majestie]
will c
o
tinue to speake to
M
r
Car
o
in c
o
for[mitie of]
t
w
c
I have
posed. Whereof I knowe fr[om time]
to time he will advertise those of Holland, [which will]
quicken th
e
muche against
e time. [The]
g
na
l States
, who appointed to meete about [the middle]
of this moneth, are not like to come togeth[er, till]
e ende of
e next. For some of
e Provinces, [as it]
seemeth, will not yeld to c
o
tribut, as it hat[h bin]
re
q
red, to
e next sommers service. Whereby [it is]
supposed, it will be late er they beginne, and [happily]
for this s
o
mer they will doe very little. I[t is]
the opinion of some,
t
they will onely attempt [the]
blocking of
Gertrudenbergh
and make exc[ursions]
into
Brab
a
t,
w
t
out exploiting any thing [else:]
albeit it is said,
t
e
States of Friseland
[will]
endevour in like m
a
ner
e blocking of
Gr[oeninghen.]
The
Count Solmes
is come hither o[ut of]
Zeland
, to re
q
re some helpe of those of Ho[lland]
for making a certaine roade, about
e quarter [s of]
Hulst
, wherto they will graunt him a 1000 souldiers [.]
Whereas I have written heeretofore,
t
M
r
Buzenval
had moved
e States in
e
Kings
behalfe, to aid
him this s
o
mer w
t
2000 m
e
for 3 or 4 monethes, all
fol.6r
e c
o
tributing Provinces,
Utrecht
excepted, have passed
their consents to paye to
t
purpose 2500
li
ste
r
every
moneth, for 4 monethes together, and to leave
u
to the
King, to levie
e men. But this is onely so c
o
cluded in
e
Provinces a
t, w
c
must be confirmed at their g
na
l
meeting, where we hope
t
those of Utrecht will assent
w
t
e rest: albeit it is thought, if they should not,
t
e
rest of
e Provinces will supply their deffect.
They are greatly heere in
q
sitive, to knowe in w
at
maner
they shall be holp
e
by her M
tie
in respect of
e C
o
tract.
W
c
I signify is a mater unknow
e
unto me. But yet
I speake, as of my self,
t
considering
e import
a
ce of
e
actions of
Fr
a
ce
, and
t
all
t
they doe heere, is to very
litle purpose, if
e King be overthow
e
, I thinke her
Hig
es
will determine to imploye all her meanes, as well
of her auxiliary forces in these c
o
treis, as of others fr
o
home, to assiste
e F
r
King: and will endevour to induce
e people of this c
o
trey, to c
o
vert their charges also
t
way, and to maintaine heere at home but a defensive
warre. There is a meaning thereup
o
, as is tolde
me by some, if her Hig
es
give over to assist th
e
any
longer, to dissolve out of hand
e
Councel of Estate
.
They beginne to renue an old c
o
plaint, as
touching
e service mony of
e Cautionary townes, by
reason they are surcharged w
t
some bandes above
e Tre
a
ty.
And in
e garrison of
Flushing
they will not allowe
e
c
o
panies of
S
r
Matthew Morgan
and
S
r
Coniers Clifford
to be
of 200 till they sue their c
o
mission for it. Being
writt
e
unto about it fr
o
S
r
Edmund Udal
, I have wished him
in any wise, to give good speeches to
e Burgmasters, and to
intreate th
e
to c
o
tinue their accoustumed course in lodging
all
e souldiers till her M
tie
shall be pleased to sette some
other order: and if th
e
thereup
o
they will not doe as
heertofore, to shewe them in good termes,
t
he should be
forced therein to use some autoritie for
e avoiding of
disorder
t
might growe by suche souldiers, as having no
lodging would goe loosely straggling in
e night.
The
States of Holland
have newly conferred up
o
the
fol.6v
sonne
of
e
Princesse of Orenge
Henry [Frederick]
of Nassau, a regiment of 20 c
o
panies, and [have]
allowed him a pay of 80
li
ste
r
by
e moneth [But]
c
o
ditionally
t
it shall be to maintene him for a [while]
at
e schoole. It is also secretly repo[rted that]
there is a matche c
o
cluded w
c
shall be shortely [solem-]
nised betweene
e
Co
u
t Palatin
of
e Rhine, a[nd the]
eldest daughter
of
e
Prince of Orenge
, by hi[s
wife
]
of
e house of Bourbon, who is heere w
t
e Pri[ncess,]
of 18 yeres of age. It is thought
t
[this Easter]
e Princesse herselfe w
t
all her traine, and
e res[t of the]
sisters will bring her to
e Palsgrave. [Of the]
Enemies actions heere is very little notice, as [we have]
never had it better. It is said notw
t
standing, [that the]
Count Mansfeld
, w
t
the Councel of estate [doth]
direct all affaires: and
t
Count Charles
his [son]
doeth c
o
mand
e troupes
t
goe for Fr
a
ce: w
c
are [thought]
to be 600 foote, and 1500 horse. But as yet w[e can not]
heere,
t
they are passed
e frontiers.
And [thus I]
take my humble leave. Fr
o
e Hage [.]
